abstract: Reporters are arrested in Zuccotti Park, CBS presents its new “Early Show” lineup and Google is expected to announce its own online music-download store.
snippet: Reporters are arrested in Zuccotti Park, CBS presents its new “Early Show” lineup and Google is expected to announce its own online music-download store.
lead_paragraph: The day after the nighttime raid that cleared protesters from Zuccotti Park, the New York Police Department was criticized by local politicians and news organizations for its treatment of reporters and the restrictions it placed on how they do their work. The Associated Press reported that at least half a dozen reporters were arrested in and around the park, home of the Occupy Wall Street movement, including a reporter and photographer from the agency. Michael Oreskes, senior managing editor for The A.P., said: “Journalists should not be restricted from access to news events or detained for attempting to do their jobs. We were unhappy that two of our staff members were swept up in the police operation, but we appreciate the N.Y.P.D.’s decision to release them.”

abstract: Google Music will sell individual tracks as well as full albums, letting customers store the files in “cloud” accounts. Customers will be allowed to share music by offering friends one free chance to listen to any purchased track.
snippet: Google Music will sell individual tracks as well as full albums, letting customers store the files in “cloud” accounts. Customers will be allowed to share music by offering friends one free chance to listen to any purchased track.
lead_paragraph: 8:26 p.m. | Updated Looking to extend its reach as a hub for entertainment and social networking, Google introduced a set of music features on Wednesday, including a download store to compete with iTunes.

headline.main: Google Opens a Digital Music Store
